turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I got it.  Piece of cake.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Go!  I'll finish here.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Ready to rock?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Ready.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: John, get out of the way!!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: SHOOT!!!!

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: I know.  This is a dream, Sarah.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Oh.  Yeah.  They... make me take this stuff...

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: I love you.  I always will.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Oh, God... Kyle.  I need you so much.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: They took him from me.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: It's John who's the target now.  You have to protect him.  He's wide open.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I know!

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Don't quit, Sarah.  Our son need you.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I know, but I'm not as strong as I'm supposed to be.  I can't do it.  I'm screwing up the mission.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Remember the message... the future is not set. There is not fate but what we make for ourselves.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Kyle, don't go!

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: There's not much time left in the world, Sarah.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: It has helped me a lot to have a goal, something to look forward to.

turns.speaker: SILBERMAN
turns.text: And what it that?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You said I could be transferred to the minimum security wing and have visitors if I showed improvement in six months.  Well, it's been six months, and I was looking forward to seeing my son.

turns.speaker: SILBERMAN
turns.text: I see.  Let's go back to what you were saying about these terminator machines.  Now you think they don't exist?

turns.speaker: SILBERMAN
turns.text: But you've told me on many occasions about how you crushed one in a hydraulic press.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: If I had, there would have been some evidence. They would have found something at the factory.

turns.speaker: SILBERMAN
turns.text: I see.  So you don't believe anymore that the company covered it up?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: So what do you think, Doctor?  I've shown a lot of improvement, haven't I?

turns.speaker: SILBERMAN
turns.text: You see, Sarah... here's the problem.  I know how smart you are, and I think you're just telling me what I want to hear.  I don't think you really believe who you've been telling me today.

turns.speaker: SILBERMAN
turns.text: You broke my arm!

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: There's 215 bones in the human body, motherfucker. That's one.  Now don't move!

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You're already dead, Silberman.  Everybody here dies.  You know I believe that.  So don't fuck with me!

turns.speaker: SILBERMAN
turns.text: Open the goddamn door!

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: This T-1000... what happens when you shoot it?

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: Ballistic penetration shocks it, but only for a few seconds.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Can it be destroyed?

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: Unknown.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You look like handmade shit.

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: So do you.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I'll bet. Makes you a more efficient killer, right?

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: Correct.

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: My CPU is a neural-net processor... a learning computer.  But Skynet presets the switch to "read-only" when we are sent out alone.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Doesn't want you thinking too much, huh?

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: The man most directly responsible is Miles Bennet Dyson, Director of Special Projects at Cyberdyne Systems Corporation.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Why him?

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: In a few months he creates a revolutionary type of mircoprocessor.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Then what?

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: In three years Cyberdyne will become the largest supplier of military computer systems.  All stealth bombers are upgraded with Cyberdyne computers, becoming fully unmanned,  Afterward, the fly with a perfect operational record.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Uh huh, great.  Then those fat fucks in Washington figure, what the hell, let a computer run the whole show, right?

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: Basically.  The Skynet funding bill is passed.  The system goes on-line August 4th, 1997.  Human decisions are removed from strategic defense.  Skynet begins to learn, at a geometric rate.  It becomes self-aware at 2:14 a.m. eastern time, August 29. In a panic, they try to pull the plug.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: And Skynet fights back.

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: Yes.  It launches its ICBMs against their targets in Russia.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Why attack Russia?

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: Because Skynet knows the Russian counter-strike will remove its enemies here.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Jesus.  How much do you know about Dyson?

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: I have detailed files.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I want to know everything.  What he looks like. Where he lives.  Everything.

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: The CPU from the first terminator.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Son of a bitch, I knew it!

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: I must be destroyed.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Can you get us in there, past security?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Is it safe for them here?

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: Take your kids.  Go to a hotel.  Right now. Don't pack.  Let's go.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: It's finally over.

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: No.  There is another chip.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Are you afraid?

turns.speaker: TERMINATOR
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: VIDEO SARAH
turns.text: ... it's... like a giant strobe light, burning right through my eyes... but somehow I can still see.  Look, you know the dream's the same every night, why do I have to --

turns.speaker: VIDEO SILBERMAN
turns.text: Please continue...

turns.speaker: VIDEO SARAH
turns.text: It's not just a dream.  It's real, you moron! I know the date is happens!!

turns.speaker: VIDEO SILBERMAN
turns.text: I'm sure it feels very real to you --

turns.speaker: VIDEO SARAH
turns.text: On August 29th 1997 it's going to feel pretty fucking real to you, too!  Anybody not wearing number two million sunblock in gonna have a real bad day, get it?

turns.speaker: VIDEO SILBERMAN
turns.text: Relax now, Sarah --

turns.speaker: VIDEO SARAH
turns.text: You think you're alive and safe, but you're already dead.  Everybody, you, him...  everybody... you're all fucking dead!

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Where do you stand on all this?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: On all what?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: On Furtwängler.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: You represent the United States now. We have a moral duty to be just and we have to be seen to be just.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Major Arnold believes he has a moral duty, too.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Our duty is to help Furtwängler with his defence,  That's why I want you to look at this...  These are part of the transcripts of the trial at Nuremberg. We can't get them translated fast enough. But I guess you understand German, right?

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: That's because you had a proper upbringing.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: That's right. I was raised very strictly. So don't speak before you are spoken to!

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: Oh! And don't wave your hands about!

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Respect your elders and your betters!

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: And no elbows on the table!

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Eating is eating... and...

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: And talking is talking! Well, I think we better get on.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Right. So, this is going to be very formal, too, now. Lieutenant David Wills requests die pleasure of die company of Fraulein Emmi Straube at dinner any night she cares.

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: What does he mean, too correct?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: Don't see me to my door, there's no need.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: But I promised your mother.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Yesterday I read that Furtwängler was asked to lead the New York Philharmonic back in '36, Toscanini suggested it. Had he accepted, he would have become the most celebrated conductor in America.

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: When he made his decision, he couldn't have known everything. Especially not the way people like you do, who've returned from exile and feel that you have a right to pass judgement. Because you are blameless, you think you know best who is a sinner and who deserves forgiveness. But you have no idea how people lived here.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: When he met Hitler at his birthday and shook hands with him, was he pleased?

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: I don't know. But you and I already know that he has saved lives.

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: 'Please remember that Dr. Furtwängler risked his life to help anyone who asked him. I personally testify to having seen literally hundreds of people lined up outside his dressing room after concerts to ask for his help. He never turned anyone away. After he heard me play... I am a violinist... he gave me money because I was unable to feed myself or my family and then he helped me to escape to Sweden. He helped countless people in similar ways.'

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: And this, only one of these letters, Major. I have lots of them.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Lieutenant Wills reporting to Major Arnold. Sir.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: For Chrissakes I hate that shit, cut it out.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I'm very sorry.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I'm Steve. What's your name?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: David. David Wills. I'm your liaison officer with the Allied Kommandatura Cultural Affairs Committee. Sir.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Sounds a lot of run.  So they sent the big guns to check up on me. We recruiting children now?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I guess so, sir.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You call me sir again and I'll make you listen to Beethoven.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Where you from, David?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: was born here, in Leipzig. I escaped in '36. My parents, they sent me to my uncle in Philadelphia. They were to follow. But they delayed and...

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I guess you admire musicians.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Some.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Don't. This is like a criminal investigation, David. Musicians, morticians, doctors, lawyers, butchers, clerks. They're all the same.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You think a whole orchestra, what, a hundred and forty or so guys, could be orchestrated?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I guess it's possible.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: So, what does the Russki want?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Colonel Dymshitz asked specially to see you.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: 'Dim-shits'?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: What the hell are they doing?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: They're trying to sort out some of the works of art the Nazis stole from occupied territories. Who really owns what? That's Colonel Dymshitz, on the far side.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: David, need to ask you something. You heard this rumour the British found something called the Hinkel Archive?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: So what is it?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: The British occupy the building where this guy, Hinkel, ran the Nazi Ministry of Culture and it seems they've... they've discovered his secret archive.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: What's that mean?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I don't know, but the British are excited about it, I know that. The rumour is Hinkel kept a file on every artist working in the Third Reich.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Jeez. And you think the British'll share it with their Allies?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Major Richards said he'd call to let us know.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: That's big of him.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Okay, better question the next witness. I bet you a bottle of French champagne he tells us the baton story inside ten minutes.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Five minutes.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: It's a bet. You're the witness, Emmi.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You have a question for Helmuth, David?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Yes. What was the orchestra's reaction when they asked you to play for Hitler's birthday?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Yes, David?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Why not show Dr. Furtwängler the evidence. It may refresh his memory?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You see, Wilhelm, I'm talking about ordinary, everyday reasons. Which is why I want to discuss your private life.  How many illegitimate children do you have?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Major, I don't see how this line of questioning could...

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: David, what are you Counsel for the Defence now?  Did you hear the question?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Isn't it true that before every concert you got a woman in your dressing room and gave her the old conductor's baton, isn't that true?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Major, this is deeply offensive and repugnant!

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You bet.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: and totally irrelevant.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Not so, Counsellor. That secretary of yours, she wasn't just your secretary, she procured women for you, didn't she? As many and as often as you wanted.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Major, that's not a good argument. If Dr. Furtwängler did indeed enjoy all these... these privileges, he enjoyed them because of who he is and what he is. That's true of any leading artist in any country in the world.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: But it still doesn't make them saints. They still have to get up and piss in the middle of the night, don't they? They can still be vindictive and envious and mean just like you and me. Well, just like me. Can't they?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Your manner.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: My manner? Why don't you go downstairs, get a cup of coffee and calm down? What's the matter, Emmi? What's going on with you? What's wrong?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Can I ask you a favour, Major?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: When you question him again, could you treat him with more respect?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: With more what? More what?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Major, he may just be the greatest conductor of this century and that merits respect.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: David, I don't understand a thing about you. You're a Jew. Are you a Jew?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Yes, I'm a Jew. But I like to think first I'm a human being.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: A human being, oh, good, I'm relieved, I thought you were going to say you were a music lover. This man, this great artist has made anti-Semitic remarks like you wouldn't believe. I got letters.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Major, show me someone who hasn't made an anti-Semitic remark and I'll show you the gates of paradise.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: What is it with you, David? Where are your feelings? Where's your hatred, your disgust? Where's your fucking outrage, David?

turns.speaker: DYMSHITZ
turns.text: Hello, Major, my name is Dymshitz. I'm glad to see you.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Colonel. Pleasure.

turns.speaker: DYMSHITZ
turns.text: So, Major, tell me, have you questioned Dr. Furtwängler?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Not yet.

turns.speaker: DYMSHITZ
turns.text: I've had two meetings with him. He's a great musician. Maybe the greatest conductor in the world. His Brahms, Beethoven, Schubert - unequalled.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I was in Vienna. I had with me an Austrian chauffeur, Max his name was, he spent time in the camps. We were looking at these Viennese cleaning up the bomb damage, scavenging for rotting food, butt ends, anything. I said, 'To think a million of these people came out to welcome Adolf on the day he entered the city, a million of 'em, and now look at 'em.'  And Max said, 'Oh, not these people, Major. These people were all at home hiding Jews in their attics.' You get the point, Colonel? The point is they're all full of shit.

turns.speaker: DYMSHITZ
turns.text: Furtwängler's in a different category.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: We're dealing with degenerates here.

turns.speaker: DYMSHITZ
turns.text: A great artist will have great privileges in a Russian zone.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: That's why he didn't get the hell out of here when he had the chance! I put that to him, he couldn't answer. Why didn't he go and direct in America, like that Italian, Toscanini.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Colonel. He had no sisters, no brothers, only a lot of love affairs.

turns.speaker: DYMSHITZ
turns.text: Anyway, Major, why should he leave his country, his mother tongue, his family, his history, his past, his future, just because now, suddenly, there is a dictatorship? Why?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: But what... before that turns rotten...  What if they surround the space with barbed wire, Colonel?

turns.speaker: DYMSHITZ
turns.text: Don't talk about things you know nothing about. He was in a dictatorship!

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Yeah, yeah, art and politics, yeah, yeah, I heard all about that.

turns.speaker: DYMSHITZ
turns.text: In a dictatorship, art belongs to the Party. If you want to be a conductor, you have to have an orchestra. And you can only get an orchestra if you have contact with the power. All over the world you need the right contacts and you have to make the right compromises.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: This is what I'm saying. He must have had Party contacts.

turns.speaker: DYMSHITZ
turns.text: There are good Party members who help, and there are dirty non-Party members who inform on you. Of course, they gave him privileges.

turns.speaker: DYMSHITZ
turns.text: And suddenly, Steve, suddenly you notice that they like you. They honour you, suddenly you are the director of the best museum in the world, for example.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: What museum?

turns.speaker: DYMSHITZ
turns.text: I'm sorry. Museum? Not... I said orchestra. Sorry. Believe me.  Help me, Steve. You say you answer for someone from high up. I, too, have orders from high up. Very high up. We want Furtwängler. I'll give you in return the whole orchestra, four, five conductors. I need him, Steve.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: No can do.

turns.speaker: DYMSHITZ
turns.text: Let Furtwängler go. Please.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I have a duty.

turns.speaker: DYMSHITZ
turns.text: Duty? I am sorry, duty? Duty fucking duty. Trouble is, you Americans want everybody to live like you. We liberated Berlin, Major Steve, not you. Our duty also is to bring back the best of German culture.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I'm gonna get that fucking bandleader, Colonel. No deal. No fucking deal.

turns.speaker: DYMSHITZ
turns.text: Then you're going to kill me.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You live here, in Berlin?

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You do shorthand and typing?

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Okay, let's see. How long were you in the camp for?

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: Three months.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Says here because of your father. What's that mean?

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: My father was one of the officers in the plot against Hitler. They arrested the plotters and their families.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Your mother, too.

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: Yes. She suffered longer. She was in Ravensbruck.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: And your father was executed.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Steve.

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: There have been messages for you.  A Lieutenant David Wills called from the Allied Kommandatura Cultural Affairs office in Wiesbaden. I don't know who he is.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Think you can get me any of that?

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: Oh yes, Major, I have recordings of all his symphonies. I kept them safe during the bombing. My favourite is the Seventh Symphony.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Mine's the Eleventh.

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: But... he only wrote nine, Major.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I'm kidding, Emmi. What about a record player? You have that, too?

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: No. Ours was damaged.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: What's in those files?

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: The names of the members of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra since 1934 together with their questionnaires.  Major, what am I to tell Dr. Furtwängler?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You tell him nothing, Emmi. If he calls again, you say you know nothing. We're gonna keep him waiting while I get acquainted with his case and with the witnesses. And, God help me, with Beethoven.

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Come in, Emmi, this is your office, too. Emmi, this is Lieutenant David Wills.

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: Major, Major... he's here ...

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Shut the door, Emmi. Sit down, Emmi. We're going to keep him waiting, too.

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: Bruckner's Seventh, Major.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Do you know where the Adagio begins?

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Put it on ready to play, and I'll tell you when to play it.

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: I'm sorry but I have to leave. I'll find other work. You'll have to get someone else, that's all.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: What is this, Emmi?

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: I can't do this. It's not right.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: What's not right?

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: I have been questioned by the Gestapo just like that. Just like you questioned him.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Emmi, stop! I want to show you something. Let me show you something and then if you want to leave, you can leave, please please. His friends, they did this. And he gave them birthday concerts.

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: But he had no idea, a lot of people had no idea. I only realised what was really going on when I got arrested.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: If he had no idea, why did the Jews need saving? This is the question, Emmi, to all Germans: Why did the Jews need saving in this country? Why, if people had no idea?

turns.speaker: EMMI
turns.text: I would like to go now, please.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I want you to understand why you're here. You're automatically banned from public life under Control Council Directive No 24. We're here to look into your case before you appear in front of the Tribunal for Artists of the Denazification Commission. You understand that?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I have already been cleared by a Denazification Tribunal in Austria.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: What they do in Austria doesn't interest me one little bit. Okay? I have your questionnaire here,  Gustav Heinrich Ernst Martin Wilhelm Furtwängler, born Berlin, January 1886. Orchestral conductor. And you say here you were never a member of the Nazi Party.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: That is correct.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Could you tell us about being made a Prussian Privy Councillor. How did that happen to a non-Party member?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I received a telegram from Hermann Goering informing me that he had made me a Privy Councillor. I was not given the opportunity either to accept or refuse. After the dreadful events of November 1938, the violent attacks on the Jews, I stopped using the title.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: What about Vice-President of the Chamber of Music, you used that title didn't you? But then I suppose you had no choice there either, because I suppose Dr. Goebbels just sent you a telegram saying, Dear Mr. Vice-President.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I don't think Dr. Goebbels sent me a telegram. I was simply told. In a letter, I believe. I don't remember exactly.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Goebbels and Goering were sure heaping honours on you. One makes you a Privy Councillor, the other makes you Vice-President of the Chamber of Music, and you weren't even a member of the Party, how do you explain that?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: Well, there was a constant battle between Goering and Goebbels as to which of them would control German culture. I was simply a pawn. Anyway, I resigned from the Musikkammer at the same time I resigned as Musical Director of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra. In 1934.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Then why did you conduct at one of their Nuremberg rallies?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I did not conduct at at the rally, I conducted on the evening before the rally.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: That sounds like the small print in one of our insurance policies, Wilhelm. And what about April 19, 1942?  The eve of Hitler's fifty- third birthday, the big celebration; you conducted for Hitler, didn't you? Was that in keeping with your view that art and politics have nothing to do with each other?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: That... that was a different matter, I... I was tricked.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: How come?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: Could I have a glass of water, please? Please, Fraulein?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I made no deal!

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I don't buy that.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: It's the truth.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I keep hearing you helped a lot of Jews to escape. How did you do that?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I don't remember in detail, there were so many.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Did you call someone you knew?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I may have, as... as I said, I simply don't remember.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Let me me help you, then. You picked up the phone and made a call -  'Hello, Adolf? Wilhelm speaking. Listen, old pal, there's a Jew-boy musician I want you to help. He needs a permit to get to Paris.'

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Or maybe you called Goebbels or Goering? You were so close you were in the same shithouse as them.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: May I ask a question?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: When will my case be heard by the Tribunal?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Your guess is as good as mine.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I need to work. I need to make my living. I live off the generosity of friends...

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Tough, tough!

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: Then why is it, please, that another conductor who was actually a member of the Party, who used to play the Horst Wessel before his concerts, has already been cleared and is working again while I have to wait and wait and wait?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I don't know, he wasn't my case. Why did you escape to Switzerland just before the war ended?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: It was because I learned that the Gestapo was about to arrest me.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Why were they going to arrest you?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I believe it was because of another letter I'd written to Goebbels lamenting the decline of musical standards due to racial policies.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You didn't complain about the racial policies, just about the musical standards, is that right?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: So, how did you learn that the Gestapo was out to get you?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: During an enforced hour-long interval because of a power failure at a concert here in Berlin, Albert Speer, the Minister of Armaments, said to me, 'You look very tired Dr. Furtwängler, you should go abroad for a while.' I knew exactly what he meant.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You sure knew a lot of people in high places.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: It would be truer to say, I think, that a lot of people in high places knew me.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You were real close to all of them, to Adolf, to Hermann, to Joseph, to Baldur, and now Albert,  So, let's hear the truth, let's come clean. What was your Party number?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: If you are going to bully me like this, Major, you had better do your homework. You obviously have no idea how impertinent and stupid your questions are.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I have a list of names here, people in your profession, who got out in '33. Bruno Walter, Otto Klemperer, Arnold Schoenberg, Max Reinhardt...

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: They were Jews, they had to leave. They were right to leave.  I could not leave my country in her deepest misery. After all, I am a German.  I... I stayed in my homeland. Is that my sin in your eyes?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: See, David? He can't answer the question. I'll ask it again, Wilhelm, and don't give me any more airy-fairy, intellectual bullshit!

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Steve Arnold...

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I've had enough of this, I'm leaving.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I've got to hand it to the British, David. You know what those guys are?  Decent.  Tell me, Herr Dr. Furtwängler, do you know Hans Hinkel?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: Yes, a despicable human being. He was in the Ministry of Culture. His job was to get rid of Jews in the arts.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Yup, that's him, that's the guy. You know what else the little creep did? He kept files, close on 250,000 files. And you know what's in those files?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: Certainly not, but I knew he had informers everywhere. Even in my orchestra there was someone

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I wasn't told. I just knew it.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I was warned.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Who warned you?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: Goering. Because Hinkel was working for Goebbels.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: What did Goering say?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: He told me to be careful as one of Goebbels' men was watching me. He read a report on me - everything I said was quoted word by word.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Oh boy, you're gonna love this. Take your time with this now. Those files contain the details of every working artist in this country. Those files are gonna tell us who joined the Party, who informed and who was helpful.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: It is now nine o'clock precisely. I do not intend to be kept waiting again.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Don't talk to me like I was a second violinist. Go back into the waiting room. Miss Straube will come and get you when I am ready to see you.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: If it's too hot, open your tie.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I wish to say something.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Go ahead, be my guest.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: When I last saw you, I was unprepared. I did not know what to expect. In these past weeks, I have been thinking more carefully and making some notes.  You have to understand who I am and what I am. I am a musician and I believe in music. I am an artist and I believe in art. Art in general, and music, in particular, has for me mystical powers which nurture man's spiritual needs. I must confess, however, to being extremely naive.  I insisted for many years on the absolute separation of art and politics. My entire life was devoted to music because, and this is very important, because I thought that I could, through music, do something practical.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: And what was that?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: Maintain liberty, humanity and justice.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Gee, that's a thing of beauty, honest to God, a real thing of beauty. I'm going to try to remember that. Liberty, humanity and justice. Beautiful. But you used the word 'naive'. Are you now saying you think you were wrong? That art and politics can't be separated?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I believe art and politics should be separate, but that they weren't kept separate I learned to my cost.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: And when did you first learn that - when you sent the telegram? Was that the surrender signal, the waving of the white flag?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: What telegram?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: 'Happy birthday, dear Adolf, love Wilhelm.' Or words to that effect. That sounds to me like you were dropping on your knees and saying, 'Okay, Adolf, you win. You're the number one man. Have a swell party.'

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I have no idea what you're talking about.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: The birthday greetings you sent to your old pal, Adolf Hider.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I never sent him any birthday greetings or any other kind of greetings.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Think carefully, Wilhelm... maybe not in your own name, but as Privy Councillor or Vice-President.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I don't have to think carefully. This is utterly ridiculous.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: You won't find it because no such telegram exists.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Well, I tried, you got to admit I tried. I thought I might just trap you there, Wilhelm, but David here was too quick for me. Smart move, David, smart move. No, I don't have the telegram, but I know it exists. And I want you to know, Wilhelm, we're going to keep looking for it because I believe you sent it.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: Then you are wrong.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Art and politics, yeah, art and politics. Let's look at that. You and the Berlin Philharmonic toured the Third Reich, played in countries the Nazis had conquered. Are you saying that conducting in occupied territories from 1939 on wasn't a commercial for Adolf and all he stood for?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: We never, never officially represented the regime when we played abroad. We always performed as a private ensemble. As I think I already told you, I was a freelance conductor.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You know something? You should've written our insurance policies for us because you got more exclusion clauses than Double Indemnity. What do you imagine people thought? The Berlin Philharmonic's taken over by Doctor Goebbels and his Propaganda Ministry but Wilhelm is a freelance, so art and politics are now entirely separate? Is that what you believed ordinary people thought?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: have no idea what ordinary people thought.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: No, because I had only one intention. My only intention whatever I did was to show that music means more than politics.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Tell me about von der Null.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: Von der Null?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Yes, von der Null.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: Von der Null?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: How long's this going to go on, Wilhelm? I say von der Null, you say von der Null, I say von der Null, you say von der Null, we could go on all day. You know who von der Null is, don't you? Edwin von der Nuell, music critic.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: Yes, I know who he is.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Isn't it true that because he gave you bad reviews and praised this young guy, Von Karajan, called him a goddamn miracle, said he was a better conductor than you, then you had von der Null conscripted into the army and no one's heard from him since?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: That's an outrageous lie!

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You sure you didn't call one of your close buddies and say, God in heaven, did you see what that guy von der Null wrote about me? The greatest conductor on earth. I want him out the way. He had the nerve to accuse me I am not playing enough modern music. Send him to Stalingrad. Isn't that what you did? You don't like criticism, do you, Wilhelm?  You surely didn't like them saying there was another conductor who was better than you... Are you saying the name von der Null was never mentioned in your talks with Goebbels?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: Well. Once he said he'd read what this man wrote about me.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: And what did he say?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: He said, 'Don't mind him. His job is to criticise, your job is to conduct.'

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: And what happened to Von der Nul?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I have no idea.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You've really no idea? I'll tell you what happened. He died in Stalingrad.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Now, that young conductor what's his name?  That miracle kid, you know who I mean. Von Karajan! But you called him something else. C'mon. What did you call von Karajan?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: Please stop playing these games with me. Why you should bring up the name of another conductor is beyond my understanding.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I'll tell you why. You remember we talked about you playing for Hitler's birthday?  And you told me that Goebbels got to your doctors first, that you were tricked?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: Yes, that's what happened.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Come on, admit it. K worried you, didn't he? He always worried you. In 1942, he's thirty-four years old, you're already fifty-six. And Goebbels and Goering keep saying to you, 'If you don't do it, little K will.' Never mind art and politics and symbols and airy-fairy bullshit about liberty, humanity and justice because I don't care how great you are. It's the oldest story in the book,  The ageing Romeo jealous of the young buck. The real reason you didn't leave the country when you knew you should have was that you were frightened that, once you were out of the way, you'd be supplanted by the Miracle Kid, the Party's boy twice over, flashy, talented little K.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: This is absolute nonsense!

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Well, I'm just beginning to develop my theme. Isn't that what you call it in classical music, developing your theme? Okay, so they played on your insecurity. That's human, understandable. But, there is one guy who doesn't like little K as much as he likes you - yeah, the number one man your old pal, Adolf. He thinks you're the greatest, and when he says, I want Wilhelm for my birthday, boy, they better go out get Wilhelm. So, Josef calls and threatens you with little K. And you said to hell with the Ninth in Vienna, I'll give it to Adolf as a birthday present in Berlin. That's the trick they played, they got you by the balls and they squeezed. Hard. Why did you stay? Why did you play for them? Why were you the flag-carrier for their regime?  Jealousy?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: Of course there was a conspiracy against me, a campaign - even abroad.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I have illegitimate children.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I said I have illegitimate children. I don't know how many.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You like the women, don't you, Wilhelm?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: Stop this, please, stop this now!

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: No, I'm not going to stop it. Hitler himself offered you a beautiful house and a personal bomb shelter.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I absolutely refused the house and the bomb shelter.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: But you see what I'm getting at? You get a gorgeous house, you're highly paid. What are you gonna do, stay or leave? One voice comes back at me: stay!

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Okay, Wilhelm, go home now. Go home and think about these past twelve years.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I don't understand what you mean.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: No, that's your problem, Wilhelm. You understand nothing. We'll call you. Go!

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Everybody says what a great benefactor you were to the Jews. But--  I have things here you said and wrote. Listen to this: 'The Jew composer Schonberg is admired by the Jewish International.' And what about this: 'Jewish musicians lack a genuine affinity with our music.' 'Jewish musicians are good businessmen with few scruples, lacking roots.' You deny you said these things?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: Those attitudes do not exist in me.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I believe that. But just answer the question, don't give me explanations.

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: Speaking to Party members I used their language, of course I did, everyone did.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Do you know what that is?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: Of course I know what that is.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Okay, so what is it?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: Bruckner's Seventh. The Adagio.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Who's conducting?

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: How can I know such a thing?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I'll tell you, then. The last time this music was played on these air waves was after they announced that your pal Hitler had shot himself. Listen to it.  They listen. Did they pick little K's recording? Did they pick some other conductor? No, they picked you, and why? Because you represented them so beautifully. When the Devil died, they wanted his bandleader to conduct the funeral march. You were everything to them.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Have you ever smelled burning flesh? I smelt it four miles away. Four miles away, I smelt it. Have you ever seen the gas chambers, the crematoria? Have you seen the mounds of rotting corpses? You talk to me about culture, art and music? You putting that in the scales, Wilhelm? You setting culture, art and music against the millions put to death by your pals? They had orchestras in the camps. They played Beethoven, Wagner. The hangmen were playing chamber music at home with their families. I don't understand the Germans' relationship with music. What do you need music for? Your pals you could call to save a few Jews when millions of them were being annihilated? Yes, I blame you for not getting hanged, I blame you for your cowardice. You strutted and swaggered, you fucking piece of shit, king-pin in a shithouse. You talk to me about walking a tightrope between exile and the gallows, and I say to you, lies!

turns.speaker: FURTWÄNGLER
turns.text: I love my country, I believe in music, what was I to do?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Look around you. See the country you served. Look at people who had real courage, who took risks, who risked their lives. Like Emmi's father.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Helmuth Alfred Rode. Second violinist since 1935. What's it mean, second violinist?

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: It means I wasn't good enough to be a first violinist.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Good, and according to your questionnaire, Helmuth, you never joined the Nazi Party.

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: Me? Never.  Never.

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: Is it true you're going to interview Dr. Furtwängler today?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I'll ask the questions, Helmuth.

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: Excuse me. Did you know that he refused to give the Nazi salute when Hitler was present in the audience?

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: Oh, we didn't play for his birthday, we played the evening before - it was the 19th of April not the 20th.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Do you know Hans Hinkel?

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: Do I know Hans Hinkel?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: That's what I asked.

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: Do I know Hans Hinkel?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You seem to understand the question, now how about answering it?

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: Hans Hinkel was in the Ministry of Culture; how could I know such a man?  I

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: I hear the British have his... his archive, files, records.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Do you know what's in this archive?

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: How could I know what's in the archive?

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: Major.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Helmuth.

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: Guess what I am holding in my hand. You like guessing games?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Love 'em, Helmuth. I give up. What are you holding in your hand?

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: It's Dr. Furtwängler's baton, which I stole.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: The one he kept in his right hand. Yes, you remember.

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: Yes, you remember.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: How could I forget?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Show me.

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: Show you?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Yeah, show me, I want to see you do it. Pretend I'm Adolf. You're the maestro, and you have the baton in your right hand, but you give me the salute just the same.

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: Not here, Major, there are people, if anybody should see... please, please, Major...

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Do it, Helmuth.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: And I see what you mean. You nearly poked my eyes out.

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: Exactly.  Replaces the baton, gives Steve the case.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Don't worry, Helmuth, it'll be our secret.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Great catch, kid. The boy runs off.

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: So. You wanted to see me.

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: You usually don't work on Sunday, Major?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: All in the cause of humanity, Helmuth. Or should I call you one- zero-four-nine-three-three-one?

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: One-zero-four-nine-three-three- one. Or d'you mind if I just call you 'one'?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Was a member of...?  Speak up?

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: I was a member of the Communist Party. I was a communist. That's what Hinkel had over me. He knew everything. He held that over me. That's how he made me co-operate.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Oh, I see, he made you co-operate. And now are you a communist again?

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: You don't know what it's like to wake up every single morning of your life terrified, you don't know that -

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I can give you freedom of movement, freedom to work, freedom, Helmuth. But I need something in return.

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: Major, we're discussing a man of genius, I don't want...

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Fuck that, Helmuth. You want to discuss symbols here?  This guy was a front man. He was the piper, but he played their tune, you get my philosophical meaning?  I'm not interested in small fish, I'm after Moby Dick. Come on, Helmuth. Hard facts.

turns.speaker: RODE
turns.text: The only thing I know is he's an anti-Semite.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Of course. You, too. Like everyone else in this goddamn country.
